lg.l: maṭalaviḻ, kāṉal variyum vēṉil van tiṟutteṉa
To the eminent young prince Iḷaṅkō of the western Cēra kings,
Who was in the enclosure at the eastern entrance,
The hill inhabitants, having come together, said:
‘In the beautiful, shining, rich shade under the golden-flowered kino tree,
The king of the immortals (Indra) and his retinue gathering, having come together [on earth]
For one, holy, great Pattiṉi (wife) who was she who lost one breast
[them] having gone with her to the heavens,
As we saw [this] with our own eyes,
You must grace, having learnt of that.’
Cāttaṉ of cool Tamil who was seated beside him (Iḷaṅkō)
Saying, ‘I know [this story]! That happened!’ He would [then] narrate:
Within the ancient towns of the Cōḻaṉ with a garland and a chaplet
In the city of Pukār with undiminishing excellence
Was a merchant called Kōvalaṉ. In that town,
Because of [his] conduct, in which he dallied with
A dancing lady who praises [the art] of performance,
His wealth that was difficult [to obtain] experiencing ruin,
[He], hoping for the sale of the tinkling anklet befitting of [producing] music
From the foot of her — the lady of the house called Kaṇṇaki,
He entered Maturai of the Pāṇṭiyaṉ with big, excellent storeyed houses,
Of excellence worthy of being sung.
Having taken it [the anklet], he would go to
To the royal street [near the palace] with big shopping stalls.
As he showed [the anklet] in his hand to a smith who worked with gold,
[The smith] saying, ‘There is no connecting relationship to this anklet,
Besides [it] being the eminent lady's [= the queen].
Saying, 'I saw the anklet with fine pieces of metal [inside]
In the hand of some other thief',
Because it was the time in which [Kōvalaṉ’s] Karma came to fruition,
The man with margosa [garlands] that blossom on branches [= Pāṇṭiya king]
Being one who did not investigate at all,
Calling out to his enraged watchmen,
The wife of Kōvalaṉ who suffered the scene of murder,
Did not see [any] ground to stand on [= place to stay].
Having shed tears from [her] long eyes
Having twisted off the front of her breast on her chest with a string of pearls,
So that the Pāṇṭiyaṉ is ruined,
The Pattiṉi who is praised by many,
Who fed Kūṭal of [formerly good] status to the long flames,
[Iḷaṅkō asks] ‘You said it is the time for Karma to come into fruition. [In] what [way]?
He [Cāttaṉ] said, 'Victorious one, what [indeed] is the fruition of their Karma? Listen!
In the ancient town of Maturai of unshaken excellence,
In the middle of the night, I lay down in the silver hall [among] the public buildings in the village common
Of he with matted knot of hair, [decorated with] a laburnum flower [Śiva].
The great deity of Maturai having appeared in front of
The brave Pattiṉi who was greatly distressed,
Saying, ‘Oh you who made emerge from your breast a fury of scorching flames!
Because the ripened Karma is [now] fulfilled for you,
Because of the curse cast by the wife of a merchant
Called Caṅkamaṉ of Ciṅkapuram of undiminishing, abundant fame,
Became bound [to you with] fresh bracelets along with your husband,
[Now], Oh lady with] long, luxuriant tresses,
Leaving the limit of within two-seven (= fourteen) days,
Apart from in the form of celestial beings,
There will be no seeing [anymore] of your husband
In the form of those in this world [= earthly form]’;
[Cātaṉ] saying, ‘The one who listened to this deceitless narration was I. [Because of]
The becoming of duty into Death for those who deviate from their kingly nature,
The praise by eminent people for Pattiṉi who is deserving of praise,
The [repeated] saying that ripened Karma, having taken form, will feed [on you],
The tinkling anklet being the reason for [that] planned Karma,
Let us establish a singular poem that possesses songs/smaller stanzas.
It [must be] suitable for all three kings that have crowns.
Oh eminent one, only you can grace [such a composition]!’
To he who said [the above], as he [Iḷaṅkō],
The chapter in which elders dutifully established a household,
The chapter of the lady Mātavi’s [first] ascension upon a stage
The chapter that made excellent of the twilight-evening,
The chapter in which the town took on the Indra festival,
The chapter of bathing in the sea,
The chapter on the seashore grove where Palmyra fronds open,
The chapter in which Mātavi lamented because the hot season came and stayed,
The chapter that narrated the manner of the evil-possessing dream
The chapter of seeing the [Pāṇṭiya] land by the manner of questioning,
The chapter of seeing the forest,
The Vari_dance of the hunting tribe,
The chapter in which [Kaṇṇaki] stayed in the outer quarters with [the lady with] the garland on which petals open,
The chapter of seeing the noisy town,
The chapter of refuge for the lady worthy of excellence,
The chapter of the place of the murder,
The Kuravai dance of the cowherdresses,
The garland of sorrow in which the fiery matter [= murder] was heard,
The Vari dance in which the midday that shivered surrounded the town,
The chapter of explaining [good] conduct to the king who is worthy of excellence,
The chapter of the fire happening,
The chapter of the narration, the rare god having appeared,
The Kuravai dance upon the hills by ladies with garlands that open with honey,
With all of these that are called [so],
[The chapters of] the sight, the taking of the stone, the water-offering,
The herostone, the praise, along with the chapter of giving boons,
As the eminent one worthy of praise graced
All the six-five [= thirty chapters above],
[As a] verse that possess songs, in the middle of which prose was placed,
The grain-merchant Cāttaṉ from Maturai listened.
This is the custom of the Patikam, that knew the manner of dividing it.
